title: How to Make Avocado Fries

steps.headline: Heat the oil until it reaches the right temperature.
steps.description: Fill a medium, heavy-bottomed saucepan with approximately 1 ½ inches (4 cm) of canola oil. Place a deep fry or candy thermometer in the pan, and heat the oil on medium to medium-high until it reaches 375 degrees Fahrenheit (190 degrees Celsius). If you have a table top deep fryer, you can cook the avocado fries in it. Preheat the oil to 375 degrees Fahrenheit (190 degrees Celsius) just as you would in a pan.

steps.headline: Combine the flour and salt.
steps.description: Add ¼ cup (31 g) of flour and ¼ teaspoon (1 ½ g) of kosher salt to a shallow dish. Mix the two together well with a fork to ensure that they’re fully blended. You can substitute whole wheat flour for the all-purpose if you prefer. If you like, you can also mix some freshly ground black pepper into the flour to season it.

steps.headline: Place eggs and panko in separate dishes.
steps.description: Gather two more shallow dishes and place them beside the flour. Crack 2 large eggs into one, whisking them so they’re slightly beaten. Add 1 ¼ cup (62 ½ g) of panko breadcrumbs to the other dish. You can substitute regular bread crumbs for the panko if you prefer.

steps.headline: Dip the avocado slices in the flour, egg, and panko in order.
steps.description: For the fries, you’ll need 2 firm, ripe avocado that have been pitted, peeled, and sliced into ½-inch (13-cm) wedges. Dredge the wedges in the flour and shake off the excess. Next, dip the wedges into the egg and then directly into the panko to coat. Make sure that all of the wedges are well coated with the breadcrumbs on all sides. Have a plate or platter nearby that you can lay the avocado fries on once you’ve coated them.

steps.headline: Fry the avocado slices in the oil until golden brown.
steps.description: When the oil has reached 375 degrees Fahrenheit (190 degrees Celsius) in the pan, add just enough of the avocado wedges that will fit in a single layer. Fry the fries until they are golden brown, which should take 30 to 60 seconds. Repeat with the remaining wedges. Use a slotted, metal spoon to lift the avocado fries out of the oil so the excess oil can drip off.

steps.headline: Drain on a paper towel lined plate before serving.
steps.description: When you’re finished frying the avocado fries, place them on a plate lined with paper towel. Allow them to sit for a minute or two so the excess oil is absorbed before serving them. These simple avocado fries pair best with a spicy dipping sauce, such as jalapeno ketchup.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and prepare the pan.
steps.description: To ready the oven for baking the fries, set the temperature to 400 degrees Fahrenheit (200 degrees Celsius) and allow it to fully heat. Next, pour 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of canola oil to a large sheet pan or baking dish and spread it around to grease it. You can substitute olive or vegetable oil for the canola if you prefer.

steps.headline: Squeeze the lime juice over the avocados and season with salt and pepper.
steps.description: The fries require 2 large avocados that have been pitted, peeled, and cut into ½-inch (13-mm) slices. Sprinkle the juice from half of a lime over the avocados, and add some salt and pepper to taste. Adding the lime juice is an optional step, but it will help keep the avocado fries from becoming discolored as you work.

steps.headline: Mix the flour with the seasonings.
steps.description: Add ¼ cup (31 g) flour of flour to a shallow dish. Next, whisk in ½ tsp (1 ½ g) of garlic powder, ½ tsp (1 ½ g) of onion powder, and ½ tsp (1 g) of paprika into the flour until the ingredients are well-blended. You can adjust the amount of the seasonings or add in some of your own. For example, cayenne pepper can add a spicy kick, while cumin can add some smoky flavor.

steps.headline: Place the egg and panko in separate dishes.
steps.description: Set two more shallow dishes beside the flour mixture. Add a lightly beaten egg to one of the dishes and 1 cup (50 g) of panko breadcrumbs to the other. You can substitute regular bread crumbs for the panko if you prefer.

steps.headline: Dip the avocado slices in the flour, egg, and panko in order.
steps.description: To ready the fries for baking, dredge the avocado wedges in the seasoned flour. Next, dip them in the egg and press into the panko to coat them well. Make sure that all sides of the avocado fries are coated with the panko.

steps.headline: Place the avocados in a single layer on the pan and add the remaining oil.
steps.description: After the fries are coated, set them down on a single layer on the oiled pan or baking dish. Drizzle the remaining 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of canola oil over the fries to help them become crispy during baking. You can spray the fries with an oil cooking spray instead of drizzling the oil over them if you prefer.

steps.headline: Bake the avocado fries until they are golden.
steps.description: Place the avocado fries in the preheated oven. Allow them to bake for approximately 15 minutes or until they become golden brown. Halfway through the cooking time, flip the fries over to ensure that they cook evenly. You can add more oil or oil cooking spray to the fries as they’re baking to help them become even crispier.

steps.headline: Serve the fries with your favorite dipping sauce.
steps.description: When the avocado fries are finished baking, remove them from the oven. Transfer them to a platter, and serve with ketchup or your favorite dipping sauce. Ranch dressing and chipotle dipping sauce are tasty with the avocado fries.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven.
steps.description: To ensure that the oven is hot enough to bake the fries when they’re ready, it’s important to preheat it. Set the temperature to 400 degrees Fahrenheit (200 degrees Celsius), and allow the oven to fully heat.

steps.headline: Mix the panko, ground flax seed, and chili powder.
steps.description: Add ¾ cup (37 ½ g) of panko breadcrumbs, 2 tablespoons (14 g) of ground flaxseed, and 1 teaspoon (3 g) chili powder to a medium bowl. Whisk the ingredients together until they’re well blended. You can adjust the seasonings to suit your tastes. For even spicier fries, you may want to mix in some freshly ground black pepper and cayenne pepper.

steps.headline: Whisk the egg in a separate bowl.
steps.description: In a separate bowl, crack an egg. Use a whisk to beat it gently. You can use an egg substitute in place of the egg if you prefer.

steps.headline: Dip the avocado wedges into the egg and then the breadcrumbs.
steps.description: You’ll need 2 ripe avocados that have been pitted, peeled, and cut into ½-inch (13-mm) wedges for the fries. Dunk the wedges into the egg and then dip into the breadcrumb mixture to coat them on both sides. Place the fries on a large baking sheet. Make sure that the avocado fries are arranged in a single layer on the baking sheet so they will cook evenly.

steps.headline: Spray the fries with oil cooking spray and bake until they are crispy.
steps.description: When the fries are on the baking sheet, give them a light spritz with an oil cooking spray. Place them in the oven, and allow them to bake for 10 to 12 minutes or until they are crispy on the outside.

steps.headline: Season the fries with salt, pepper, and hot sauce before serving.
steps.description: Once the fries are finished baking, remove them from the oven. Sprinkle them with salt to taste, and allow them to cool on the baking sheet for 3 to 5 minutes. Next, transfer them to a platter and drizzle them with as much hot sauce as you’d like before serving. Because these fries are on the spicy side, it’s best to serve them with a creamy dipping sauce. Ranch is an ideal option.

tyn: Large sheet pan or baking dish
text: Frying Up Classic Avocado Fries Heat the oil until it reaches the right temperature. Fill a medium, heavy-bottomed saucepan with approximately 1 ½ inches (4 cm) of canola oil. Place a deep fry or candy thermometer in the pan, and heat the oil on medium to medium-high until it reaches 375 degrees Fahrenheit (190 degrees Celsius). If you have a table top deep fryer, you can cook the avocado fries in it. Preheat the oil to 375 degrees Fahrenheit (190 degrees Celsius) just as you would in a pan. Combine the flour and salt. Add ¼ cup (31 g) of flour and ¼ teaspoon (1 ½ g) of kosher salt to a shallow dish. Mix the two together well with a fork to ensure that they’re fully blended. You can substitute whole wheat flour for the all-purpose if you prefer. If you like, you can also mix some freshly ground black pepper into the flour to season it. Place eggs and panko in separate dishes. Gather two more shallow dishes and place them beside the flour. Crack 2 large eggs into one, whisking them so they’re slightly beaten. Add 1 ¼ cup (62 ½ g) of panko breadcrumbs to the other dish. You can substitute regular bread crumbs for the panko if you prefer. Dip the avocado slices in the flour, egg, and panko in order. For the fries, you’ll need 2 firm, ripe avocado that have been pitted, peeled, and sliced into ½-inch (13-cm) wedges. Dredge the wedges in the flour and shake off the excess. Next, dip the wedges into the egg and then directly into the panko to coat. Make sure that all of the wedges are well coated with the breadcrumbs on all sides. Have a plate or platter nearby that you can lay the avocado fries on once you’ve coated them. Fry the avocado slices in the oil until golden brown. When the oil has reached 375 degrees Fahrenheit (190 degrees Celsius) in the pan, add just enough of the avocado wedges that will fit in a single layer. Fry the fries until they are golden brown, which should take 30 to 60 seconds. Repeat with the remaining wedges. Use a slotted, metal spoon to lift the avocado fries out of the oil so the excess oil can drip off. Drain on a paper towel lined plate before serving. When you’re finished frying the avocado fries, place them on a plate lined with paper towel. Allow them to sit for a minute or two so the excess oil is absorbed before serving them. These simple avocado fries pair best with a spicy dipping sauce, such as jalapeno ketchup. Preparing Oven Baked Avocado Fries Preheat the oven and prepare the pan. To ready the oven for baking the fries, set the temperature to 400 degrees Fahrenheit (200 degrees Celsius) and allow it to fully heat. Next, pour 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of canola oil to a large sheet pan or baking dish and spread it around to grease it. You can substitute olive or vegetable oil for the canola if you prefer. Squeeze the lime juice over the avocados and season with salt and pepper. The fries require 2 large avocados that have been pitted, peeled, and cut into ½-inch (13-mm) slices. Sprinkle the juice from half of a lime over the avocados, and add some salt and pepper to taste. Adding the lime juice is an optional step, but it will help keep the avocado fries from becoming discolored as you work. Mix the flour with the seasonings. Add ¼ cup (31 g) flour of flour to a shallow dish. Next, whisk in ½ tsp (1 ½ g) of garlic powder, ½ tsp (1 ½ g) of onion powder, and ½ tsp (1 g) of paprika into the flour until the ingredients are well-blended. You can adjust the amount of the seasonings or add in some of your own. For example, cayenne pepper can add a spicy kick, while cumin can add some smoky flavor. Place the egg and panko in separate dishes. Set two more shallow dishes beside the flour mixture. Add a lightly beaten egg to one of the dishes and 1 cup (50 g) of panko breadcrumbs to the other. You can substitute regular bread crumbs for the panko if you prefer. Dip the avocado slices in the flour, egg, and panko in order. To ready the fries for baking, dredge the avocado wedges in the seasoned flour. Next, dip them in the egg and press into the panko to coat them well. Make sure that all sides of the avocado fries are coated with the panko. Place the avocados in a single layer on the pan and add the remaining oil. After the fries are coated, set them down on a single layer on the oiled pan or baking dish. Drizzle the remaining 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of canola oil over the fries to help them become crispy during baking. You can spray the fries with an oil cooking spray instead of drizzling the oil over them if you prefer. Bake the avocado fries until they are golden. Place the avocado fries in the preheated oven. Allow them to bake for approximately 15 minutes or until they become golden brown. Halfway through the cooking time, flip the fries over to ensure that they cook evenly. You can add more oil or oil cooking spray to the fries as they’re baking to help them become even crispier. Serve the fries with your favorite dipping sauce. When the avocado fries are finished baking, remove them from the oven. Transfer them to a platter, and serve with ketchup or your favorite dipping sauce. Ranch dressing and chipotle dipping sauce are tasty with the avocado fries. Whipping Up Spicy Avocado Fries Preheat the oven. To ensure that the oven is hot enough to bake the fries when they’re ready, it’s important to preheat it. Set the temperature to 400 degrees Fahrenheit (200 degrees Celsius), and allow the oven to fully heat. Mix the panko, ground flax seed, and chili powder. Add ¾ cup (37 ½ g) of panko breadcrumbs, 2 tablespoons (14 g) of ground flaxseed, and 1 teaspoon (3 g) chili powder to a medium bowl. Whisk the ingredients together until they’re well blended. You can adjust the seasonings to suit your tastes. For even spicier fries, you may want to mix in some freshly ground black pepper and cayenne pepper. Whisk the egg in a separate bowl. In a separate bowl, crack an egg. Use a whisk to beat it gently. You can use an egg substitute in place of the egg if you prefer. Dip the avocado wedges into the egg and then the breadcrumbs. You’ll need 2 ripe avocados that have been pitted, peeled, and cut into ½-inch (13-mm) wedges for the fries. Dunk the wedges into the egg and then dip into the breadcrumb mixture to coat them on both sides. Place the fries on a large baking sheet. Make sure that the avocado fries are arranged in a single layer on the baking sheet so they will cook evenly. Spray the fries with oil cooking spray and bake until they are crispy. When the fries are on the baking sheet, give them a light spritz with an oil cooking spray. Place them in the oven, and allow them to bake for 10 to 12 minutes or until they are crispy on the outside. Season the fries with salt, pepper, and hot sauce before serving. Once the fries are finished baking, remove them from the oven. Sprinkle them with salt to taste, and allow them to cool on the baking sheet for 3 to 5 minutes. Next, transfer them to a platter and drizzle them with as much hot sauce as you’d like before serving. Because these fries are on the spicy side, it’s best to serve them with a creamy dipping sauce. Ranch is an ideal option.
sentences: Frying Up Classic Avocado Fries Heat the oil until it reaches the right temperature.
Fill a medium, heavy-bottomed saucepan with approximately 1 ½ inches (4 cm) of canola oil.
Place a deep fry or candy thermometer in the pan, and heat the oil on medium to medium-high until it reaches 375 degrees Fahrenheit (190 degrees Celsius).
If you have a table top deep fryer, you can cook the avocado fries in it.
Preheat the oil to 375 degrees Fahrenheit (190 degrees Celsius) just as you would in a pan.
Combine the flour and salt.
Add ¼ cup (31 g) of flour and ¼ teaspoon (1 ½ g) of kosher salt to a shallow dish.
Mix the two together well with a fork to ensure that they’re fully blended.
You can substitute whole wheat flour for the all-purpose if you prefer.
If you like, you can also mix some freshly ground black pepper into the flour to season it.
Place eggs and panko in separate dishes.
Gather two more shallow dishes and place them beside the flour.
Crack 2 large eggs into one, whisking them so they’re slightly beaten.
Add 1 ¼ cup (62 ½ g) of panko breadcrumbs to the other dish.
You can substitute regular bread crumbs for the panko if you prefer.
Dip the avocado slices in the flour, egg, and panko in order.
For the fries, you’ll need 2 firm, ripe avocado that have been pitted, peeled, and sliced into ½-inch (13-cm) wedges.
Dredge the wedges in the flour and shake off the excess.
Next, dip the wedges into the egg and then directly into the panko to coat.
Make sure that all of the wedges are well coated with the breadcrumbs on all sides.
Have a plate or platter nearby that you can lay the avocado fries on once you’ve coated them.
Fry the avocado slices in the oil until golden brown.
When the oil has reached 375 degrees Fahrenheit (190 degrees Celsius) in the pan, add just enough of the avocado wedges that will fit in a single layer.
Fry the fries until they are golden brown, which should take 30 to 60 seconds.
Repeat with the remaining wedges.
Use a slotted, metal spoon to lift the avocado fries out of the oil so the excess oil can drip off.
Drain on a paper towel lined plate before serving.
When you’re finished frying the avocado fries, place them on a plate lined with paper towel.
Allow them to sit for a minute or two so the excess oil is absorbed before serving them.
These simple avocado fries pair best with a spicy dipping sauce, such as jalapeno ketchup.
Preparing Oven Baked Avocado Fries Preheat the oven and prepare the pan.
To ready the oven for baking the fries, set the temperature to 400 degrees Fahrenheit (200 degrees Celsius) and allow it to fully heat.
Next, pour 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of canola oil to a large sheet pan or baking dish and spread it around to grease it.
You can substitute olive or vegetable oil for the canola if you prefer.
Squeeze the lime juice over the avocados and season with salt and pepper.
The fries require 2 large avocados that have been pitted, peeled, and cut into ½-inch (13-mm) slices.
Sprinkle the juice from half of a lime over the avocados, and add some salt and pepper to taste.
Adding the lime juice is an optional step, but it will help keep the avocado fries from becoming discolored as you work.
Mix the flour with the seasonings.
Add ¼ cup (31 g) flour of flour to a shallow dish.
Next, whisk in ½ tsp (1 ½ g) of garlic powder, ½ tsp (1 ½ g) of onion powder, and ½ tsp (1 g) of paprika into the flour until the ingredients are well-blended.
You can adjust the amount of the seasonings or add in some of your own.
For example, cayenne pepper can add a spicy kick, while cumin can add some smoky flavor.
Place the egg and panko in separate dishes.
Set two more shallow dishes beside the flour mixture.
Add a lightly beaten egg to one of the dishes and 1 cup (50 g) of panko breadcrumbs to the other.
You can substitute regular bread crumbs for the panko if you prefer.
Dip the avocado slices in the flour, egg, and panko in order.
To ready the fries for baking, dredge the avocado wedges in the seasoned flour.
Next, dip them in the egg and press into the panko to coat them well.
Make sure that all sides of the avocado fries are coated with the panko.
Place the avocados in a single layer on the pan and add the remaining oil.
After the fries are coated, set them down on a single layer on the oiled pan or baking dish.
Drizzle the remaining 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of canola oil over the fries to help them become crispy during baking.
You can spray the fries with an oil cooking spray instead of drizzling the oil over them if you prefer.
Bake the avocado fries until they are golden.
Place the avocado fries in the preheated oven.
Allow them to bake for approximately 15 minutes or until they become golden brown.
Halfway through the cooking time, flip the fries over to ensure that they cook evenly.
You can add more oil or oil cooking spray to the fries as they’re baking to help them become even crispier.
Serve the fries with your favorite dipping sauce.
When the avocado fries are finished baking, remove them from the oven.
Transfer them to a platter, and serve with ketchup or your favorite dipping sauce.
Ranch dressing and chipotle dipping sauce are tasty with the avocado fries.
Whipping Up Spicy Avocado Fries Preheat the oven.
To ensure that the oven is hot enough to bake the fries when they’re ready, it’s important to preheat it.
Set the temperature to 400 degrees Fahrenheit (200 degrees Celsius), and allow the oven to fully heat.
Mix the panko, ground flax seed, and chili powder.
Add ¾ cup (37 ½ g) of panko breadcrumbs, 2 tablespoons (14 g) of ground flaxseed, and 1 teaspoon (3 g) chili powder to a medium bowl.
Whisk the ingredients together until they’re well blended.
You can adjust the seasonings to suit your tastes.
For even spicier fries, you may want to mix in some freshly ground black pepper and cayenne pepper.
Whisk the egg in a separate bowl.
In a separate bowl, crack an egg.
Use a whisk to beat it gently.
You can use an egg substitute in place of the egg if you prefer.
Dip the avocado wedges into the egg and then the breadcrumbs.
You’ll need 2 ripe avocados that have been pitted, peeled, and cut into ½-inch (13-mm) wedges for the fries.
Dunk the wedges into the egg and then dip into the breadcrumb mixture to coat them on both sides.
Place the fries on a large baking sheet.
Make sure that the avocado fries are arranged in a single layer on the baking sheet so they will cook evenly.
Spray the fries with oil cooking spray and bake until they are crispy.
When the fries are on the baking sheet, give them a light spritz with an oil cooking spray.
Place them in the oven, and allow them to bake for 10 to 12 minutes or until they are crispy on the outside.
Season the fries with salt, pepper, and hot sauce before serving.
Once the fries are finished baking, remove them from the oven.
Sprinkle them with salt to taste, and allow them to cool on the baking sheet for 3 to 5 minutes.
Next, transfer them to a platter and drizzle them with as much hot sauce as you’d like before serving.
Because these fries are on the spicy side, it’s best to serve them with a creamy dipping sauce.
Ranch is an ideal option.
